snippet: Works by Chopin were the highlight of a performance by the pianist Louis Lortie, who stepped in for Maurizio Pollini on Sunday at Carnegie Hall.
abstract: Zachary Woolfe reviews performance by pianist Louis Lortie, who stepped in to replace an injured Maurizio Pollini, at Carnegie Hall. Photo (M)
lead_paragraph: In May 2003 the pianist Louis Lortie made his Carnegie Hall debut, replacing an injured Maurizio Pollini. He triumphed in a daunting program, playing all three sets of Chopin's études. Mr. Pollini is once again ailing. Health issues have caused him to cancel a series of engagements in the United States, including two solo recitals at Carnegie. On April 29, Garrick Ohlsson stepped in for the first, and on Sunday afternoon, almost exactly nine years after the last time, Mr. Lortie again did the honors.

headline.main: A Substitute Adept at Rounding Hairpin Turns
